questions.question: What is Overdose's core values statement?

answers.text: Break the rules. Think bigger. Get sh*t done.
answers.textHtml: Break the rules. Think bigger. Get sh*t done.

answers.text: Deliver on time. Stay on budget. Keep clients happy.
answers.textHtml: Deliver on time. Stay on budget. Keep clients happy.

answers.text: Work hard. Play hard. Win big.
answers.textHtml: Work hard. Play hard. Win big.

answers.text: Quality first. Speed second. Profit third.
answers.textHtml: Quality first. Speed second. Profit third.

questions.feedback: Overdose's core values are captured in the phrase 'Break the rules. Think bigger. Get sh*t done.' — challenging convention, aiming for transformation, and executing relentlessly.
questions.feedbackHtml: Overdose's core values are captured in the phrase 'Break the rules. Think bigger. Get sh*t done.' — challenging convention, aiming for transformation, and executing relentlessly.

questions.question: What is the key difference between the traditional agency model and Overdose's Anti-Agency approach?
questions.questionHtml: What is the key difference between the traditional agency model and Overdose's Anti-Agency approach?

answers.text: Traditional agencies optimize for delivery; we optimize for business outcomes
answers.textHtml: Traditional agencies optimize for delivery; we optimize for business outcomes

answers.text: Traditional agencies charge less than we do
answers.textHtml: Traditional agencies charge less than we do

answers.text: Traditional agencies use older technology
answers.textHtml: Traditional agencies use older technology

answers.text: Traditional agencies have larger teams
answers.textHtml: Traditional agencies have larger teams

questions.feedback: The core difference is that traditional agencies measure success by project delivery ('on time, on budget'), while we measure success by actual business outcomes and results for clients.
questions.feedbackHtml: The core difference is that traditional agencies measure success by project delivery ('on time, on budget'), while we measure success by actual business outcomes and results for clients.

questions.question: What does 'Break the rules' mean at Overdose? (Select all that apply)
questions.questionHtml: What does 'Break the rules' mean at Overdose? (Select all that apply)

answers.text: Questioning industry conventions that don't serve clients
answers.textHtml: Questioning industry conventions that don't serve clients

answers.text: Breaking legal and ethical guidelines
answers.textHtml: Breaking legal and ethical guidelines

answers.text: Taking smart risks instead of playing it safe
answers.textHtml: Taking smart risks instead of playing it safe

answers.text: Trying new approaches that might produce better results
answers.textHtml: Trying new approaches that might produce better results

questions.feedback: 'Break the rules' means challenging industry norms, taking smart risks, and trying new approaches — NOT breaking legal, ethical, or contractual rules. It's about purposeful innovation, not chaos.
questions.feedbackHtml: 'Break the rules' means challenging industry norms, taking smart risks, and trying new approaches — NOT breaking legal, ethical, or contractual rules. It's about purposeful innovation, not chaos.

questions.question: What combination of traits defines successful ODers?
questions.questionHtml: What combination of traits defines successful ODers?

answers.text: Low ego and high standards
answers.textHtml: Low ego and high standards

answers.text: High ego and low expectations
answers.textHtml: High ego and low expectations

answers.text: Strong opinions and reluctance to compromise
answers.textHtml: Strong opinions and reluctance to compromise

answers.text: Technical skills and no interest in soft skills
answers.textHtml: Technical skills and no interest in soft skills

questions.feedback: Successful ODers combine low ego (accepting feedback, admitting mistakes, helping others) with high standards (not accepting mediocre work, pushing for better, holding themselves accountable).
questions.feedbackHtml: Successful ODers combine low ego (accepting feedback, admitting mistakes, helping others) with high standards (not accepting mediocre work, pushing for better, holding themselves accountable).

questions.question: What is the Anti-Agency approach to meetings?
questions.questionHtml: What is the Anti-Agency approach to meetings?

answers.text: Every meeting should have a clear purpose and end with actions
answers.textHtml: Every meeting should have a clear purpose and end with actions

answers.text: The more meetings the better for collaboration
answers.textHtml: The more meetings the better for collaboration

answers.text: Meetings should always be at least an hour long
answers.textHtml: Meetings should always be at least an hour long

answers.text: Everyone in the company should be invited to important meetings
answers.textHtml: Everyone in the company should be invited to important meetings

questions.feedback: Meetings at OD should have a clear purpose, include only necessary people, require preparation, and end with clear actions and decisions. Time is precious.
questions.feedbackHtml: Meetings at OD should have a clear purpose, include only necessary people, require preparation, and end with clear actions and decisions. Time is precious.

questions.question: When you make a mistake at Overdose, what should you do?
questions.questionHtml: When you make a mistake at Overdose, what should you do?

answers.text: Own it immediately, explain what happened without excuses, fix it, and share what you learned
answers.textHtml: Own it immediately, explain what happened without excuses, fix it, and share what you learned

answers.text: Hide it and hope no one notices
answers.textHtml: Hide it and hope no one notices

answers.text: Blame the circumstances or other people
answers.textHtml: Blame the circumstances or other people

answers.text: Wait until someone finds out before addressing it
answers.textHtml: Wait until someone finds out before addressing it

questions.feedback: At OD, we handle mistakes by owning them immediately, explaining what happened without excuses, fixing the issue or proposing how to fix it, and sharing what we learned. Accountability builds trust.
questions.feedbackHtml: At OD, we handle mistakes by owning them immediately, explaining what happened without excuses, fixing the issue or proposing how to fix it, and sharing what we learned. Accountability builds trust.

questions.question: What does 'ownership mentality' mean at Overdose?

answers.text: Seeing work through to outcomes, solving problems proactively, and accepting accountability
answers.textHtml: Seeing work through to outcomes, solving problems proactively, and accepting accountability

answers.text: Owning company shares
answers.textHtml: Owning company shares

answers.text: Doing everything yourself without asking for help
answers.textHtml: Doing everything yourself without asking for help

answers.text: Taking credit for all team accomplishments
answers.textHtml: Taking credit for all team accomplishments

questions.feedback: Ownership mentality means caring about outcomes (not just your deliverable), solving problems instead of just flagging them, taking initiative, and accepting accountability. It doesn't mean doing everything alone or taking others' credit.
questions.feedbackHtml: Ownership mentality means caring about outcomes (not just your deliverable), solving problems instead of just flagging them, taking initiative, and accepting accountability. It doesn't mean doing everything alone or taking others' credit.

questions.question: What is the recommended approach for your first 30 days at Overdose?
questions.questionHtml: What is the recommended approach for your first 30 days at Overdose?

answers.text: Absorb — watch, listen, learn, ask questions, focus on understanding
answers.textHtml: Absorb — watch, listen, learn, ask questions, focus on understanding

answers.text: Try to change everything immediately
answers.textHtml: Try to change everything immediately

answers.text: Stay quiet and don't ask any questions
answers.textHtml: Stay quiet and don't ask any questions

answers.text: Focus only on your immediate tasks without building relationships
answers.textHtml: Focus only on your immediate tasks without building relationships

questions.feedback: In your first 30 days, the focus should be on absorbing — watching, listening, learning, asking lots of questions, understanding how things work, and building relationships with immediate teammates. Earn trust before trying to influence.
questions.feedbackHtml: In your first 30 days, the focus should be on absorbing — watching, listening, learning, asking lots of questions, understanding how things work, and building relationships with immediate teammates. Earn trust before trying to influence.
